raw_text:
Blair returns from peace mission
 
 Prime Minister Tony Blair has arrived back from his diplomatic mission to the Middle East to try to resurrect the peace process.
 
 Mr Blair held talks with his Israeli counterpart, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas. He confirmed that a renewed drive to reform the Palestinian Authority and address security issues would come at a London conference in March. Mr Blair also made a surprise trip to Iraq this week. The Israelis described the meeting as important but said they would not need to attend. Mr Blair briefly visited the tomb of Yasser Arafat in Ramallah - the first world leader to do so. He nodded briefly towards the tomb, rather than lay a wreath, in what Palestinian officials said was a compromise gesture agreed at the last minute.
 
 The BBC's Paul Reynolds says the London conference will be a limited measure to shore up the leadership of Mahmoud Abbas, also known as Abu Mazen, who is expected to win the Palestinian presidential election on 9 January. At a news conference following talks with Mr Blair, Mr Abbas said the British prime minister was "in a unique position to help us progress in our peaceful pursuit". He added: "Your endeavour to hold a conference in London is another example of your deep commitment to this purpose." In an interview with the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr, Mr Blair said getting progress between Israelis and Palestinians would be "tough, but at least we have got the first step". Mr Blair acknowledged some people believed he was too close to the Israelis, but said the Israelis were entitled to expect Palestinians to give up terrorism. He argued that Mr Sharon was committed to the internationally-agreed roadmap peace plan and said his bid to disengage from Gaza had to be part of the peace process, not the end of it. Earlier, Mr Sharon again said he had not seen "the slightest step" the Palestinians were working to end terror attacks - though he acknowledged Palestinian leaders were in the middle of an election campaign that could be hampering their efforts. Before visiting Israel, Mr Blair made a surprise visit to Iraq, where he met leaders in Baghdad during his first trip to the city. He was briefed on preparations for the national poll, which is scheduled for next month but is threatened by a deadly campaign of insurgent violence. He also flew to Basra in southern Iraq where British forces are stationed.
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a concise summary of the text:

Tony Blair has returned from his peace mission in the Middle East and attended talks with Israeli counterpart Ariel Sharon and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas.
Blair confirmed plans for a London conference in March to address security issues, which will shore up Abbas' leadership.
The BBC reports that Abbas said Blair's efforts were "in a unique position" to help progress peaceful relations.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair returns from Middle East peace mission, met with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, announced plans for London conference in March to address security issues and reform the Palestinian Authority, made surprise visit to Iraq and visited the tomb of Yasser Arafat.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair returned from a Middle East peace mission and plans a London conference in March to reform the Palestinian Authority and address security issues.
He met with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, made a surprise trip to Iraq for meetings on the upcoming national election, and visited the tomb of Yasser Arafat.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Prime Minister Tony Blair returns from his Middle East diplomatic mission and will attend a London conference to address peace efforts with Abbas.
Blair says the meeting is an important step but acknowledges some Palestinians still want to see Israel withdraw from Gaza.
Blair hopes the talks can help move forward peace negotiations, but acknowledges that achieving a lasting resolution remains a challenge.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Prime Minister Tony Blair returns from Middle East mission, meeting with Israeli leader and Palestinian president about peace talks and security issues, including holding a London conference on March 9th.
Blair visited the tomb of Yasser Arafat without laying a wreath as agreed but did so in an attempt to compromise.
qwen2.5:3b: Blair returns from Middle East peace mission; held talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.
London conference planned for March to support Palestinian Authority leadership, led by Abbas.
Blair visited Yasser Arafat's tomb briefly without laying a wreath as an agreement.
He praised the UK's role in supporting peace efforts.
Also met with Iraqi leaders before his Iraq visit.
Sharon expressed skepticism about Palestinians' progress towards ending terror attacks but acknowledged their election campaign could hinder.

Blair returns from peace mission

Prime Minister Tony Blair has arrived back from his diplomatic mission to the Middle East to try to resurrect the peace process.
Mr Blair held talks with his Israeli counterpart, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas.
He confirmed that a renewed drive to reform the Palestinian Authority and address security issues would come at a London conference in March.
Mr Blair also made a surprise trip to Iraq this week.
The Israelis described the meeting as important but said they would not need to attend.
Mr Blair briefly visited the tomb of Yasser Arafat in Ramallah - the first world leader to do so.
He nodded briefly towards the tomb, rather than lay a wreath, in what Palestinian officials said was a compromise gesture agreed at the last minute.

The BBC's Paul Reynolds says the London conference will be a limited measure to shore up the leadership of Mahmoud Abbas, also known as Abu Mazen, who is expected to win the Palestinian presidential election on 9 January.
At a news conference following talks with Mr Blair, Mr Abbas said the British prime minister was "in a unique position to help us progress in our peaceful pursuit".
He added: "Your endeavour to hold a conference in London is another example of your deep commitment to this purpose."
In an interview with the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr, Mr Blair said getting progress between Israelis and Palestinians would be "tough, but at least we have got the first step".
Mr Blair acknowledged some people believed he was too close to the Israelis, but said the Israelis were entitled to expect Palestinians to give up terrorism.
He argued that Mr Sharon was committed to the internationally-agreed roadmap peace plan and said his bid to disengage from Gaza had to be part of the peace process, not the end of it.

Earlier, Mr Sharon again said he had not seen "the slightest step" the Palestinians were working to end terror attacks - though he acknowledged Palestinian leaders were in the middle of an election campaign that could be hampering their efforts.
Before visiting Israel, Mr Blair made a surprise visit to Iraq, where he met leaders in Baghdad during his first trip to the city.
He was briefed on preparations for the national poll, which is scheduled for next month but is threatened by a deadly campaign of insurgent violence.
He also flew to Basra in southern Iraq where British forces are stationed.

tinyllama:1.1b:
The following text is a concise summary of the given passage:

Prime Minister Tony Blair returned from a diplomatic mission to Israel and the Palestinian Authority, where he met with Israeli counterpart Ari Sharon and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas.
The prime minister made a surprise visit to Iraq during his trip to the Middle East.
He briefly visited the tomb of Ya'sar Araft in Ramlaah, which is significant for the leaders attending the upcoming national election.
The passage briefly notes that the London conference will be limited in scope to secure Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas's support for progress towards a two-state solution.
Additionally, the passage highlights Tony Blair's visit to Iraq as an important move towards ensuring a peaceful future in the region.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Prime Minister Tony Blair has returned from his diplomatic mission to the Middle East, aiming to resurrect peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians.
In a joint interview with BBC political editor Andrew Marr, Mr. Blair acknowledged some people might view his involvement as too close to Israel.
However, he insisted that the Israelis were entitled to expect that his efforts would contribute to the eventual resolution of the conflict.
As the first world leader to visit Palestine in 15 years, Mr. Blair made a surprise trip to Iraq where he met with leaders in Baghdad and provided support for their nation-wide election campaign.

Talks will take place at March conference to address security issues and reform PA. Blurbs briefly visit Iraq, meets leaders in Baghdad and discusses upcoming presidential election threatened by violence.

A London conference is planned for March to address Palestinian Authority reform and security issues.
Mr. Blair visited Yasser Arafat's tomb in Ramallah, making a compromise gesture by not laying a wreath.
The London conference will support the leadership of Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, who is expected to win the presidential election on 9 January.
Mr. Blair emphasized that progress between Israelis and Palestinians would be difficult but acknowledged the commitment of Israel to the internationally-agreed roadmap peace plan.
Before visiting Iraq, he made a surprise trip to Basra, where British forces are stationed, and was briefed on preparations for the upcoming national poll in Baghdad.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Prime Minister Tony Blair returned from a Middle East diplomatic mission aimed at reviving the peace process.
He met with Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, confirming a London conference in March to support Palestinian Authority reforms and security efforts.
Blair also made a surprise visit to Iraq, meeting leaders in Baghdad and Basra.
The London conference is seen as a move to bolster Abbas, expected to win the Palestinian presidential election.
Blair acknowledged challenges in Israeli-Palestinian progress but emphasized the need for Palestinians to renounce terrorism.
Sharon reiterated concerns over Palestinian efforts to curb attacks but recognized their ongoing election campaign.
Blair's visit to Iraq included discussions on the upcoming national elections amid insurgent violence.
stablelm2:1.6b: Prime Minister Tony Blair returned from a Middle East peace mission and held talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, confirming plans for reforming the Palestinian Authority at a London conference in March and addressing security issues.
Mr. Blair also visited Yasser Arafat's tomb in Ramallah before his surprise trip to Iraq, where he met with leaders over preparations for the national poll amid ongoing violence.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Prime Minister Tony Blair has returned from a Middle East peace mission, focusing on revitalizing the Palestinian Authority's reform and addressing security concerns at an upcoming London conference in March.
During his visit, he met with Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, briefly honoring Yasser Arafat's tomb in Ramallah as a compromise gesture.
Blair emphasized the importance of the London conference for strengthening Abbas's leadership, who is expected to win the Palestinian presidential election on 9 January.
In Iraq, Blair met with local leaders in Baghdad and Basra, discussing preparations for the national poll threatened by insurgent violence.
Abbas praised Blair's commitment to the peace process, while Sharon reiterated that progress requires Palestinian action against terrorism.
Despite Sharon's concerns about the impact of the election campaign on Palestinian efforts, he acknowledged Mr. Blair's deep dedication to facilitating peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
